user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_monotonic_sec_counter:
```c
time_t
MHD_monotonic_sec_counter (void)
{
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME
  struct timespec ts;

  if ( (_MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK != mono_clock_id) &&
       (0 == clock_gettime (mono_clock_id,
                            &ts)) )
    return ts.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME */
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_timespec_t cur_time;

    if (KERN_SUCCESS == clock_get_time (mono_clock_service,
                                        &cur_time))
      return cur_time.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
#if defined(_WIN32)
#if _WIN32_WINNT >= 0x0600
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (GetTickCount64 () - tick_start)) / 1000);
#else  /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
  if (0 != perf_freq)
  {
    LARGE_INTEGER perf_counter;

    QueryPerformanceCounter (&perf_counter);   /* never fail on XP and later */
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) perf_counter.QuadPart - perf_start)
                     / perf_freq);
  }
#endif /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
#endif /* _WIN32 */
#ifdef HAVE_GETHRTIME
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (gethrtime () - hrtime_start)) / 1000000000);
#endif /* HAVE_GETHRTIME */

  return time (NULL) - sys_clock_start;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_monotonic_sec_counter:
#define HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME 1
...
#define _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK CLOCK_REALTIME
...
static clockid_t mono_clock_id = _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK
...
static time_t mono_clock_start
...
static time_t sys_clock_start
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions were found in the provided function. I inspected the code for common compiler/extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (examples: GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __builtin__ constructs, __asm, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), __declspec, __inline__ non-standard keywords, or other vendor-specific language keywords). None are present. The platform-specific APIs (clock_gettime, mach clock_get_time, GetTickCount64, QueryPerformanceCounter, gethrtime) and types (clockid_t, mach_timespec_t, LARGE_INTEGER, uint64_t, time_t) are library/OS APIs or standard C/C99 types, not language extensions. Preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef/#if) and the casts used are standard C. Although some identifiers use leading underscores (e.g. _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK), and the code is platform-specific, these are not compiler language extensions per se. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
